{{DISPLAYTITLE:(''Z'')-Stilbene}} {{chembox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 477201195 | Name = (''Z'')-Stilbene | ImageFile = Stilbene_cis_structure.svg | ImageFile1 = (Z)-Stilbene-3D-spacefill.png | ImageName1 = C=black, H=white | ImageAlt1 = (Z)-Stilbene molecule | IUPACName = ''cis''-1,2-Diphenylethylene
(''Z'')-1,2-Diphenylethene | OtherNames = ''cis''-Stilbene |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | InChI = 1/C14H12/c1-3-7-13(8-4-1)11-12-14-9-5-2-6-10-14/h1-12H/b12-11- | InChIKey = PJANXHGTPQOBST-QXMHVHEDBW | PubChem = 5356785 | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 393702 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C14H12/c1-3-7-13(8-4-1)11-12-14-9-5-2-6-10-14/h1-12H/b12-11- | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = PJANXHGTPQOBST-QXMHVHEDSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | CASNo = 645-49-8 | EINECS =211-445-7 | SMILES = c2(\C=C/c1ccccc1)ccccc2 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 36008 | ChemSpiderID = 4512351 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | C=14 | H=12 | Appearance = Liquid | Solubility = Practically insoluble | MeltingPtC = 5 to 6 | MeltingPt_notes = | BoilingPtC = 307 | BoilingPt_notes = at 1 atm (82°C to 84°C at 0.4 mmHg) }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | RPhrases = {{R36}} {{R38}} | SPhrases = {{S26}} {{S36}} | ExternalSDS = [http://msds.chem.ox.ac.uk/ST/cis-stilbene.html Oxford MSDS] }} }} '''(''Z'')-Stilbene''' is a [[diarylethene]], that is, a [[hydrocarbon]] consisting of a cis [[ethene]] double bond substituted with a [[phenyl]] group on both carbon atoms of the double bond. The name stilbene was derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word {{lang|grc|stilbos}}, which means shining. ==Isomers== Stilbene exists as two possible isomers known as [[(E)-Stilbene|(''E'')-stilbene]] and (''Z'')-stilbene. (''Z'')-Stilbene is [[steric effects|sterically hindered]] and less stable because the steric interactions force the aromatic rings out-of-plane and prevent [[conjugated system|conjugation]].{{Fact|date=June 2008}} (''Z'')-Stilbene has a melting point of {{convert|5|-|6|C}}, while (''E'')-stilbene melts around {{convert|125|C}}, illustrating that the two compounds are quite different. ==Uses== * Stilbene is used in manufacture of [[dye]]s and [[optical brightener]]s, and also as a [[phosphor]] and a [[scintillator]]. * Stilbene is one of the [[gain medium]]s used in [[dye laser]]s. ==Properties== * Stilbene will typically have the chemistry of a [[diarylethene]], a conjugated [[alkene#Reactions|alkene]]. * Stilbene can undergo [[photoisomerization]] under the influence of UV light. * Stilbene can undergo [[stilbene photocyclization]], an [[intramolecular reaction]]. * (Z)-Stilbene can undergo [[electrocyclic reaction]]s. ==Natural Occurrence== Many stilbene derivatives ([[stilbenoid]]s) are present naturally in plants. An example is [[resveratrol]] and its cousin, [[pterostilbene]]. {{DEFAULTSORT:Stilbene, (Z)-}} [[Category:Luminescence]] [[Category:Fluorescent dyes]] [[Category:Phosphors and scintillators]] [[Category:Laser gain media]] [[Category:Stilbenoids]] [[Category:Phenyl compounds]]

{{coord|34.8|-92.2|display=title}} {{refimprove|date=May 2013}} [[Image:West Virginia-Kentucky Derecho.jpg|thumb|right|325px|Map of the 1991 West Virginia Derecho (courtesy of NOAA)]]The '''1991 West Virginia derecho''' was a serial [[derecho]] (storm) that started in [[Arkansas]] in the early morning hours of April 9, 1991, and made its way northeast, finally dying out over [[Pennsylvania]] late that evening.
Two people were killed and 145 were injured in the event, mainly from falling trees, flying debris, and mobile homes and trailers being overturned. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/misc/AbtDerechos/casepages/apr91991page.htm|title=The West Virginia Derecho of 1991|website=www.spc.noaa.gov|access-date=2017-05-03}}</ref> Western and central West Virginia were affected by hail and several roads were blocked.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=|title=High winds kill 2 in west virginia.|last=|first=|date=April 10, 1991|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Most of the destructive damage occurred in [[Tennessee]], [[Kentucky]], [[West Virginia]], western [[Maryland]], and [[Western Pennsylvania]]. The fatalities associated with this storm occurred in [[Charleston, West Virginia]] and [[Huntington, West Virginia]] as a result of the high winds.<ref name=":0" />
==Damage claims== In West Virginia alone, there were 8,000 [[insurance]] damage claims for homes and businesses. Over 200,000 people lost power in the derecho. Many people experienced flickering lights and [[Voltage spike|power surges]]. This derecho was the worst [[severe weather]] event for West Virginia since the [[1974 Super Outbreak]]. <ref>[http://www.spc.noaa.gov/misc/AbtDerechos/casepages/apr91991page.htm The West Virginia Derecho of 1991]</ref>
== What is a Derecho? == There are [http://www.spc.noaa.gov/misc/AbtDerechos/derechofacts.htm several criteria] for a [[mesoscale convective system]] (MCS) to be considered a [[derecho]]. The system needs to have sustained winds of 58 mph, and stretch along a boundary at least 250 miles long. There must also be isolated wind gusts of 75 mph or greater.
== Formation of a Derecho == # There needs to be sufficient convective available potential energy ([[Convective available potential energy|CAPE]]) in the atmosphere for several thunderstorm cells to form. # There needs to be sufficient inflow of air in the lower atmosphere, with strong [[Troposphere#Divergence and convergence|upper level divergence]] in the upper atmosphere. # There needs to be an elevated [[Mixed layer#Atmospheric mixed layer formation|mixed layer]] leading to a rapid decrease in temperature with height. # There needs to be high values of vertical [[wind shear]] (45 mph or greater) in the lowest 5 kilometers of the atmosphere. # The system usually has a [[bow echo]] type of shape. This is a rather simplified list of conditions needed to form a derecho. However, when all of these conditions occur simultaneously in the atmosphere, a derecho storm system has the ''potential'' to form.
==See also== *[[List of derecho events]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.spc.noaa.gov/misc/AbtDerechos/casepages/apr91991page.htm Storm Prediction Center's "About Derechos" summary of the West Virginia Derecho of April 1991]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Act of God | image = ActOfGodPoster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Jennifer Baichwal]] | producer = [[Nicholas de Pencier]]
[[Daniel Iron]]
Jennifer Baichwal | writer = [[Paul Auster]] | starring = Paul Auster | music = [[Fred Frith]]
[[Martin Tielli]]
[[Dave Bidini]]
[[Selina Martin]] | cinematography = Nicholas de Pencier | editing = [[Roland Schlimme]] | distributor = [[Zeitgeist Films]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|2009|5|1}} | runtime = 76 minutes | country = Canada | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Act of God''''' is a 2009 Canadian documentary film that investigates the "metaphysical" effects of being [[Lightning strike|struck by lightning]].{{cite web |url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/act-of-god-483097 |title=Act of God |work=[[Allmovie]] |first=Nathan |last=Southern |accessdate=21 August 2009}} It was directed by [[Jennifer Baichwal]] (''[[Manufactured Landscapes]]'') and distributed by [[Zeitgeist Films]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zeitgeistfilms.com/film.php?directoryname=actofgod |title=Act of God |work=[[Zeitgeist Films]] |accessdate=21 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901104457/http://www.zeitgeistfilms.com/film.php?directoryname=actofgod |archivedate=1 September 2009 }} The film's world premier was at the 2009 [[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival]] at the [[Royal Ontario Museum]] in Toronto on 30 April 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotdocs.ca/index.php/audience/festival/hot_docs_opening_night_gala_in_support_of_docs_for_schools/ |title=2009 Hot Docs Opening Night Gala |work=[[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival]] |accessdate=20 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090919192109/http://www.hotdocs.ca/index.php/audience/festival/hot_docs_opening_night_gala_in_support_of_docs_for_schools |archivedate=19 September 2009 }} It went on general release in Canada on 1 May 2009, and limited release in the United States on 31 July 2009. The film's European premiere was at the 44th [[Karlovy Vary International Film Festival]] in the [[Czech Republic]] on 11 July 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.kviff.com/en/film-detail/2742-act-of-god/ |title=44th Karlovy Vary International Film Festival: Act of God |work=[[Karlovy Vary International Film Festival]] |accessdate=21 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926033857/http://www.kviff.com/en/film-detail/2742-act-of-god/ |archivedate=26 September 2009 }} ==Overview== In ''Act of God'' director Jennifer Baichwal questions whether being struck by [[lightning]] is a "random natural occurrence or a predestined event". The film contains seven stories in which Baichwal interviews people about their personal experiences with lightning strikes. She speaks to American novelist and screenwriter [[Paul Auster]], Canadian dramatist [[James O'Reilly (playwright)|James O'Reilly]], and [[United States Marine Corps|US Marine]] [[veteran]] and author [[Dannion Brinkley]]. She also interviews a [[Storm chasing|storm chaser]] in France, and a group of Mexican mothers who accept the loss of their children to lightning at a religious festival as "God's will". She also investigates a [[Yoruba religion|Yoruba]] religious community in [[Rwanda]] (the lightning capital of the world) who worship the lightning god [[Shango]]. The reactions in each of Baichwal's subjects varies considerably, from an "act of God" to the "mechanics of reality". Auster, the "philosophical anchor of the film", relates how he saw his friend being struck by lightning a short distance from him at a summer camp. Auster, 14 years old at the time, survived the incident while his friend died. Auster said "It opened up a whole realm of speculation that I've continued to live with ever since."{{cite web |url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/guides/hotdocs/2009/hotdocs.cfm?content=169180 |title=Act of God |work=[[Now (newspaper)|NOW Magazine]] |first=Norman |last=Wilner |accessdate=21 August 2009}} Yet in spite of the deep effect this event had on him, Auster insists in the film that it was "nothing more than a random occurrence". O'Reilly wrote a play called ''Act of God'' which was based on his experience with lightning. In the film O'Reilly says "I can't accept that it happened for a reason, nor can I really accept that there is no reason. The only way to carry on is to be humble, and a little bit in awe of these things you can't really understand." Brinkley was also struck by lightning and described it as "dying for 28 minutes and going up to heaven and having a completely life-transforming experience." Also present in the film is English [[experimental music|experimental]] and [[Musical improvisation|improvisational]] guitarist [[Fred Frith]]. Frith loosely ties up the stories by demonstrating that "we are electrical beings, our brains work electrically". In the laboratory of his brother, [[neuroscientist]] [[Chris Frith]], Frith improvises music on his guitar while electrical impulses in his head are recorded with a [[brain scan]], showing that "our very thoughts are akin to tiny lightning strikes in the cerebral cortex." Baichwal described improvisation as "the state of being between meaning and chance" and "it was the perfect metaphor for being struck by lightning". Frith provides the music for his segment of the film, while the [[Film score|score]] for the rest of the film comes from musicians [[Martin Tielli]], [[Dave Bidini]] and [[Selina Martin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eyeweekly.com/film/feature/article/59055 |title=Act of God: Jennifer Baichwal's electrifying new documentary finds meaning in bolts out of the blue |work=[[Eye Weekly]] |first=Jason |last=Anderson |accessdate=21 August 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Background== Jennifer Baichwal was born in [[Montreal]] where she studied for her master's degree in philosophy and theology at [[McGill University]]. Her debut feature-length film was ''Let It Come Down: The Life of Paul Bowles'' in 1998, which won her Best Biography at the 1999 [[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival]], and the 1999 [[Emmy Award#International Emmys|International Emmy]] for Best Arts Documentary.{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/article-224137/jennifer-baichwal-explores-lightning-strikes-act-god |title=Jennifer Baichwal investigates lightning strikes in Act of God |work=[[The Georgia Straight]] |first=Jessica |last=Werb |accessdate=21 August 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091004143354/http://www.straight.com/article-224137/jennifer-baichwal-explores-lightning-strikes-act-god| archivedate= 4 October 2009 | deadurl= no}} Baichwal is best known for her 2006 multiple award-winning documentary, ''[[Manufactured Landscapes]]'', which was about the Canadian artist [[Edward Burtynsky]]. Many of Baichwal's films are about artists and the creative process, but she has also explored philosophical and spiritual themes, for example in her award-winning documentary ''The Holier It Gets'', which records her journey to the source of the [[Ganges|Ganges River]] in India. ''Act of God'' looks at both the artistic and "metaphysical" side of life. Instead of using the "traditional scientific approach", Baichwal tackled the issue lightning strikes from a "philosophical point of view".{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.aol.ca/article/jennifer-baichwals-act-of-god-accidental-enlightenment/608950/ |title=Jennifer Baichwal's Act of God: Accidental Enlightenment |work=[[AOL]] Canada Entertainment |first=Chris |last=Jancelewicz |accessdate=21 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607045358/http://entertainment.aol.ca/article/jennifer-baichwals-act-of-god-accidental-enlightenment/608950/ |archivedate=7 June 2009 }} She said "Our main challenge was figuring out how to make a film about something that's totally ephemeral. I love unanswerable questions; questions like 'Is there such a thing as destiny', and 'what does it all mean?'" While research is done into the role of electricity in our brains, Baichwal wanted to find out the effect of electricity on the mind. She said that "Lightning is always cast in a scientific light [in film], unless it's used as a joke. We wanted stories that embodied that tension between meaning and chance."{{cite web |url=https://nationalpost.com/arts/story.html?id=1542705 |title=Jennifer Baichwal: Weatherproof |work=[[National Post]] |first=Chris |last=Knight |accessdate=21 August 2009}} The idea of making ''Act of God'' came to Baichwal before she started working on her previous film, ''[[Manufactured Landscapes]]''. It was during that film's development and her travels around the world to attend its screenings at film festivals that she started doing research and conducting interviews for ''Act of God''. But the final inspiration to begin work on the film came from her partner [[Nicholas de Pencier]], "a weather nerd", and the writings of lightning survivor, [[Paul Auster]]. ''Act of God'' took three years to make, which included several years of research and collecting stories from around the world of people "whose lives [were] changed by lightning". De Pencier was the film's [[cinematographer]] and co-producer. ==Critical reception== [[File:Act of God, Pencier, Baichwal.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Producer Nick de Pencier and director Jennifer Baichwal introducing ''Act of God'' at the 44th [[Karlovy Vary International Film Festival|KVIFF]].]] ''Act of God'' was selected as the Opening Night Gala feature at the 2009 [[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival]], the largest documentary film festival in North America. Chris Jancelewicz of ''[[AOL]] Canada Entertainment'' said the footage taken by Jennifer Baichwal's partner, Nick de Pencier is "nothing short of remarkable". "One of the amazing things about ''Act of God'' is Baichwal's ability to resist this urge to dictate what lightning, and ultimately chance, fate, and destiny mean in the bigger picture." Jancelewicz said that throughout the film Baichwal never imposes her views, and never comes to any conclusion, simply because "there is no conclusion to be found". Susan Noakes of ''[[CBC News]]'' described the film as an "enigmatic meditation on being struck by lightning".{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/film/story/2009/04/28/f-jennifer-baichwal-acto-of-god.html |title=Feel the electricity: Act of God is filmmaker Jennifer Baichwal's exploration of lightning strikes |work=[[CBC News]] |first=Susan |last=Noakes |accessdate=21 August 2009 | date=28 April 2009}} Jessica Werb at ''[[The Georgia Straight]]'' said the film was "one hell of a thesis". She added that while "most of us live [...] somewhere 'in the continuum of meaning and randomness'", the lives of those appearing in the film, "in one terrifying instant, swung to one extreme or the other". Norman Wilner of [[Now (newspaper)|NOW Magazine]] gave the film 4 'N's out of 5, and Nathan Southern at [[Allmovie]] gave the film 2.5 stars out of 5. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.zeitgeistfilms.com/actofgod/}} * {{IMDb title|1339043|Act of God}} * {{Allmovie title|483097|Act of God}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Act Of God}} [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Canadian documentary films]] [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:Lightning]] [[Category:Fred Frith]] [[Category:Films directed by Jennifer Baichwal]] [[Category:Documentary films about the paranormal]]

In [[geometry]], an '''affine plane''' is a system of points and lines that satisfy the following axioms:{{harvnb|Hughes|Piper|1973|page=82}} * Any two distinct points lie on a unique line. * Each line has at least two points. * Given any line and any point not on that line there is a unique line which contains the point and does not meet the given line. ([[Playfair's axiom]]) * There exist three non-collinear points (points not on a single line). In an affine plane, two lines are called ''parallel'' if they are equal or [[disjoint sets|disjoint]]. Using this definition, Playfair's axiom above can be replaced by:{{harvnb|Hartshorne|2000|page= 71}} * Given a point and a line, there is a unique line which contains the point and is parallel to the line. Parallelism is an [[equivalence relation]] on the lines of an affine plane. Since no concepts other than those involving the relationship between points and lines are involved in the axioms, an affine plane is an object of study belonging to [[incidence geometry]]. They are non-degenerate [[Linear space (geometry)|linear spaces]] satisfying Playfair's axiom. The familiar [[Euclidean plane]] is an affine plane. There are many finite and infinite affine planes. As well as [[affine plane]]s over fields (and [[division ring]]s), there are also many [[non-Desarguesian plane]]s, not derived from coordinates in a division ring, satisfying these axioms. The [[Moulton plane]] is an example of one of these.{{Citation | last1=Moulton | first1=Forest Ray | title=A Simple Non-Desarguesian Plane Geometry | jstor=1986419 | publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]] | location=Providence, R.I. | year=1902 | journal=[[Transactions of the American Mathematical Society]] | issn=0002-9947 | volume=3 | issue=2 | pages=192–195 | doi=10.2307/1986419}} ==Finite affine planes== [[File:Hesse configuration.svg|thumb|
Affine plane of order 3
9 points, 12 lines
]] If the number of points in an affine plane is finite, then if one line of the plane contains {{math|''n''}} points then: * each line contains {{math|''n''}} points, * each point is contained in {{math|''n'' + 1}} lines, * there are {{math|''n''2}} points in all, and * there is a total of {{math|''n''2 + ''n''}} lines. The number {{math|''n''}} is called the ''order'' of the affine plane. All known finite affine planes have orders that are prime or prime power integers. The smallest affine plane (of order 2) is obtained by removing a line and the three points on that line from the [[Fano plane]]. A similar construction, starting from the projective plane of order three, produces the affine plane of order three sometimes called the [[Hesse configuration]]. An affine plane of order {{math|''n''}} exists if and only if a [[projective plane#Finite projective planes|projective plane]] of order {{math|''n''}} exists (however, the definition of order in these two cases is not the same). Thus, there is no affine plane of order 6 or order 10 since there are no projective planes of those orders. The [[Bruck–Ryser–Chowla theorem]] provides further limitations on the order of a projective plane, and thus, the order of an affine plane. The {{math|''n''2 + ''n''}} lines of an affine plane of order {{math|''n''}} fall into {{math|''n'' + 1}} equivalence classes of {{math|''n''}} lines apiece under the equivalence relation of parallelism. These classes are called ''parallel classes'' of lines. The lines in any parallel class form a partition the points of the affine plane. Each of the {{math|''n'' + 1}} lines that pass through a single point lies in a different parallel class. The parallel class structure of an affine plane of order {{math|''n''}} may be used to construct a set of {{math|''n'' − 1}} [[mutually orthogonal latin square]]s. Only the incidence relations are needed for this construction. ==Relation with projective planes== {{main|Projective plane}} An affine plane can be obtained from any [[projective plane]] by removing a line and all the points on it, and conversely any affine plane can be used to construct a projective plane by adding a [[line at infinity]], each of whose points is that [[point at infinity]] where an equivalence class of parallel lines meets. If the projective plane is [[Non-Desarguesian plane|non-Desarguesian]], the removal of different lines could result in non-isomorphic affine planes. For instance, there are exactly four projective planes of order nine, and seven affine planes of order nine.{{harvnb|Moorhouse|2007|page=11}} There is only one affine plane corresponding to the [[Desarguesian plane]] of order nine since the [[Collineation|collineation group]] of that projective plane acts [[Transitive (group action)|transitively]] on the lines of the plane. Each of the three non-Desarguesian planes of order nine have collineation groups having two orbits on the lines, producing two non-isomorphic affine planes of order nine, depending on which orbit the line to be removed is selected from. ==Affine translation planes== A line {{math|''l''}} in a projective plane {{math|Π}} is a '''translation line''' if the group of elations with axis {{math|''l''}} [[Group action|acts]] [[Transitive property|transitively]] on the points of the affine plane obtained by removing {{math|''l''}} from the plane {{math|Π}}. A projective plane with a translation line is called a '''translation plane''' and the affine plane obtained by removing the translation line is called an '''affine translation plane'''. While in general it is often easier to work with projective planes, in this context the affine planes are preferred and several authors simply use the term translation plane to mean affine translation plane.{{harvnb|Hughes|Piper|1973|page=100}} An alternate view of affine translation planes can be obtained as follows: Let {{math|''V''}} be a {{math|2''n''}}-dimensional [[vector space]] over a [[Field (mathematics)|field]] {{math|''F''}}. A '''spread''' of {{math|''V''}} is a set {{math|''S''}} of {{math|''n''}}-dimensional subspaces of {{math|''V''}} that partition the non-zero vectors of {{math|''V''}}. The members of {{math|''S''}} are called the '''components''' of the spread and if {{math|''V''''i''}} and {{math|''V''''j''}} are distinct components then {{math|1=''V''''i'' ⊕ ''V''''j'' = ''V''}}. Let {{math|''A''}} be the [[incidence structure]] whose points are the vectors of {{math|''V''}} and whose lines are the cosets of components, that is, sets of the form {{math|''v'' + ''U''}} where {{math|''v''}} is a vector of {{math|''V''}} and {{math|''U''}} is a component of the spread {{math|''S''}}. Then:{{harvnb|Moorhouse|2007|page=13}} :{{math|''A''}} is an affine plane and the group of [[Translation (geometry)|translations]] {{math|''x'' → ''x'' + ''w''}} for a vector {{math|''w''}} is an automorphism group acting regularly on the points of this plane. ==Generalization: {{math|''k''}}-nets== An incidence structure more general than a finite affine plane is a {{math|''k''}}-''net of order'' {{math|''n''}}. This consists of {{math|''n''2}} points and {{math|''nk''}} lines such that: * Parallelism (as defined in affine planes) is an equivalence relation on the set of lines. * Every line has exactly {{math|''n''}} points, and every parallel class has {{math|''n''}} lines (so each parallel class of lines partitions the point set). * There are {{math|''k''}} parallel classes of lines. Each point lies on exactly {{math|''k''}} lines, one from each parallel class. An {{math|(''n'' + 1)}}-net of order {{math|''n''}} is precisely an affine plane of order {{math|''n''}}. A {{math|''k''}}-''net of order'' {{math|''n''}} is equivalent to a set of {{math|''k'' − 2}} mutually orthogonal Latin squares of order {{math|''n''}}. ===Example: translation nets=== For an arbitrary field {{math|''F''}}, let {{math|Σ}} be a set of {{math|''n''}}-dimensional subspaces of the vector space {{math|''F''2''n''}}, any two of which intersect only in {0} (called a '''partial spread'''). The members of {{math|Σ}}, and their cosets in {{math|''F''2''n''}}, form the lines of a '''translation net''' on the points of {{math|''F''2''n''}}. If {{math|1={{abs|Σ}} = ''k''}} this is a {{math|''k''}}-net of order {{math|{{abs|''F''''n''}}}}. Starting with an affine [[translation plane]], any subset of the parallel classes will form a translation net. Given a translation net, it is not always possible to add parallel classes to the net to form an affine plane. However, if {{math|''F''}} is an infinite field, any partial spread {{math|Σ}} with fewer than {{math|{{abs|''F''}}}} members can be extended and the translation net can be completed to an affine translation plane.{{harvnb|Moorhouse|2007|pages=21–22}} ==Geometric codes== Given the "line/point" [[incidence matrix]] of any finite [[incidence structure]], {{math|''M''}}, and any [[Field (mathematics)|field]], {{math|''F''}} the row space of {{math|''M''}} over {{math|''F''}} is a [[linear code]] that we can denote by {{math|1=''C'' = ''C''''F''(''M'')}}. Another related code that contains information about the incidence structure is the '''Hull''' of {{math|''C''}} which is defined as:{{harvnb|Assmus Jr.|Key|1992|page=43}} :\operatorname{Hull}(C) = C \cap C^{\perp}, where {{math|''C''⊥}} is the orthogonal code to {{math|''C''}}. Not much can be said about these codes at this level of generality, but if the incidence structure has some "regularity" the codes produced this way can be analyzed and information about the codes and the incidence structures can be gleaned from each other. When the incidence structure is a finite affine plane, the codes belong to a class of codes known as ''geometric codes''. How much information the code carries about the affine plane depends in part on the choice of field. If the [[Characteristic (field)|characteristic]] of the field does not divide the order of the plane, the code generated is the full space and does not carry any information. On the other hand,{{harvnb|Assmus Jr.|Key|1992|page=208}} * If {{math|''π''}} is an affine plane of order {{math|''n''}} and {{math|''F''}} is a field of characteristic {{math|''p''}}, where {{math|''p''}} divides {{math|''n''}}, then the minimum weight of the code {{math|1=''B'' = Hull(''C''''F''(''π''))⊥}} is {{math|''n''}} and all the minimum weight vectors are constant multiples of vectors whose entries are either zero or one. Furthermore,{{harvnb|Assmus Jr.|Key|1992|page=211}} * If {{math|''π''}} is an affine plane of order {{math|''p''}} and {{math|''F''}} is a field of characteristic {{math|''p''}}, then {{math|1=''C'' = Hull(''C''''F''(''π''))⊥}} and the minimum weight vectors are precisely the scalar multiples of the (incidence vectors of) lines of {{math|''π''}}. When {{math|1=''π'' = AG(2, ''q'')}} the geometric code generated is the {{math|''q''}}-ary [[Reed-Muller Code]]. ==Affine spaces== [[Affine space]]s can be defined in an analogous manner to the construction of affine planes from projective planes. It is also possible to provide a system of axioms for the higher-dimensional affine spaces which does not refer to the corresponding [[projective space]].{{harvnb|Lenz|1961|page= 138}}, but see also {{harvnb|Cameron|1991|loc=chapter 3}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * {{citation|last1=Assmus Jr.|first1= E.F.|last2=Key|first2=J.D.|title=Designs and their Codes|year=1992|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-41361-9}} *{{Citation | last1=Cameron | first1=Peter J. |authorlink=Peter Cameron (mathematician) | title=Projective and Polar Spaces | url=http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~pjc/pps/ | publisher=Queen Mary and Westfield College School of Mathematical Sciences | location=London | series=QMW Maths Notes | mr=1153019 | year=1991 | volume=13}} *{{citation|first=R.|last=Hartshorne|title=Geometry: Euclid and Beyond|publisher=Springer|year=2000|isbn=0387986502}} *{{citation | first1=D.|last1=Hughes|first2= F.|last2=Piper | title=Projective Planes | publisher=Springer-Verlag | year=1973 | isbn=0-387-90044-6}} *{{Citation|last=Lenz|first=H.|title = Grundlagen der Elementarmathematik|publisher = Deutscher Verlag d. Wiss.|place=Berlin|year=1961}} *{{citation|url=http://ericmoorhouse.org/handouts/Incidence_Geometry.pdf|title=Incidence Geometry|year=2007|first=Eric|last=Moorhouse}} ==Further reading== * {{Citation | last = Casse | first = Rey | title = Projective Geometry: An Introduction | publisher = Oxford University Press | place = Oxford | year = 2006 | isbn =0-19-929886-6 }} * {{Citation | last = Dembowski | first = Peter | title = Finite Geometries | publisher = Springer Verlag | place = Berlin | year = 1968}} *{{Citation | last = Kárteszi | first = F. | title = Introduction to Finite Geometries| publisher = North-Holland | place = Amsterdam | year = 1976 | isbn = 0-7204-2832-7}} *{{citation|last1=Lindner|first1= Charles C. |first2=Christopher A.|last2=Rodger|title=Design Theory|publisher=CRC Press|year=1997|isbn=0-8493-3986-3}} *{{Citation | last = Lüneburg | first = Heinz | title = Translation Planes | publisher = Springer Verlag | place = Berlin | year = 1980 | isbn = 0-387-09614-0}} *{{Citation | last = Stevenson | first = Frederick W. | title = Projective Planes | publisher = W.H. page.title: Application of silicon-germanium thermoelectrics in space exploration

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, template type. Add: bibcode. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:AquaDTRS|AquaDTRS]]
revision.text:
[[File:SiGe RTG.png|thumb|Essential components of a SiGe radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] [[Silicon-germanium]] (SiGe) [[thermoelectrics]] have been used for converting heat into power in [[spacecraft]] designed for deep-space [[NASA]] missions since 1976. This material is used in the [[radioisotope thermoelectric generators]] (RTGs) that power ''[[Voyager 1]]'', ''[[Voyager 2]]'', ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'', ''[[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]]'', [[Cassini (spacecraft)|''Cassini'']], and ''[[New Horizons]]'' spacecraft. SiGe thermoelectric material converts enough radiated heat into [[electrical power]] to fully meet the power demands of each spacecraft. The properties of the material and the remaining components of the RTG contribute towards the efficiency of this thermoelectric conversion.
== Properties == [[File:SiGe Unicouple Assembly.png|text-bottom|thumb|Components of the SiGe unicouple]] Heavily [[Doping (semiconductor)|doped]] [[semiconductors]], such as [[silicon-germanium]] ([[SiGe]]) thermoelectric couples (also called [[thermocouples]] or unicouples), are used in space exploration.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tiwari|first1=Pratibha|last2=Gupta|first2=Nishu|last3=Gupta|first3=K.M.|title=Advanced Thermoelectric Materials in Electrical and Electronic Applications|journal=Advanced Materials Research|date=April 2013|volume=685|pages=161–165|doi=10.4028/www.scientific.net/AMR.685.161|bibcode=2012AdMaR.443.1587W}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last1=Böttner|first1=H.|title=Thermoelectric Micro Devices: Current State, Recent Developments and Future Aspects for Technological Progress and Applications|journal=Twenty-First International Conference on Thermoelectrics, 2002. Proceedings ICT '02.|date=August 2002|pages=511–518|doi=10.1109/ICT.2002.1190368|isbn=978-0-7803-7683-0}}</ref>
SiGe [[alloys]] present good [[thermoelectric]] properties. Their performance in thermoelectric [[Power (physics)|power]] production is characterized by high [[Dimensionless quantity|dimensionless]] [[figure of merit|figures-of-merit]] (ZT) under high [[temperatures]], which has been shown to be near 2 in some [[nanostructured]]-SiGe models.<ref name=dingwall3>{{cite journal|last1=Dingwall|first1=F.|title=Optimization of Silicon-Germanium Thermoelectric Modules for Transportation Corps Silent Boat Design|journal=Radio Corporation of America|date=May 1963|volume=TRECOM Technical Report 63-17|url=http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/412341.pdf|id=Accession Number: AD0412341}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=Eun Kyung|last2=Yin|first2=Liang|last3=Lee|first3=Yongjin|last4=Lee|first4=Jong Woon|last5=Lee|first5=Sang Jin|last6=Lee|first6=Junho|last7=Cha|first7=Seung Nam|last8=Whang|first8=Dongmok|last9=Hwang|first9=Gyeong S.|last10=Hippalgaonkar|first10=Kedar|last11=Majumdar|first11=Arun|last12=Yu|first12=Choongho|last13=Choi|first13=Byoung Lyong|last14=Kim|first14=Jong Min|last15=Kim|first15=Kinam|title=Large Thermoelectric Figure-of-Merits from SiGe Nanowires by Simultaneously Measuring Electrical and Thermal Transport Properties|journal=Nano Letters|date=13 June 2012|volume=12|issue=6|pages=2918–2923|doi=10.1021/nl300587u|pmid=22548377|bibcode = 2012NanoL..12.2918L }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Joshi|first1=Giri|last2=Lee|first2=Hohyun|last3=Lan|first3=Yucheng|last4=Wang|first4=Xiaowei|last5=Zhu|first5=Gaohua|last6=Wang|first6=Dezhi|last7=Gould|first7=Ryan W.|last8=Cuff|first8=Diana C.|last9=Tang|first9=Ming Y.|last10=Dresselhaus|first10=Mildred S.|last11=Chen|first11=Gang|last12=Ren|first12=Zhifeng|title=Enhanced Thermoelectric Figure-of-Merit in Nanostructured p-type Silicon Germanium Bulk Alloys|journal=Nano Letters|date=10 December 2008|volume=8|issue=12|pages=4670–4674|doi=10.1021/nl8026795|pmid=19367858|bibcode=2008NanoL...8.4670J}}</ref>
SiGe alloy devices are mechanically rugged and can withstand severe shock and vibration due to its high [[Ultimate tensile strength|tensile strength]] (i.e. >7000 psi) and low [[Dislocation|dislocation density]].<ref name=dingwall3 /><ref name=xie6>{{cite journal|last1=Xie|first1=Ming|last2=Gruen|first2=Dieter M.|title=Potential Impact of ZT = 4 Thermoelectric Materials on Solar Thermal Energy Conversion Technologies|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry B|date=18 November 2010|volume=114|issue=45|pages=14339–14342|doi=10.1021/jp9117387|pmid=20196558}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Waen|first1=Jeremy G.|title=Construction and Testing of a Si/Ge Thermoelectric Unicouple For Use in the NASA JIMO Space Mission}}</ref> SiGe material is [[malleable]] with standard [[metallurgical]] equipment and bonds easily to construct components.<ref name=dingwall3 /> SiGe alloy devices can operate under high [[temperatures]] (i.e. >1300 ˚C) without degradation due to their electronic stability, low [[thermal expansion coefficient]] and high [[oxidation]] resistance.<ref name=dingwall3 /><ref name=xie6 /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jurgensmeyer|first1=Austin Lee|title=High efficiency thermoelectric devices fabricated using quantum well confinement techniques|url=http://digitool.library.colostate.edu/view/action/singleViewer.do?dvs=1426564338733~190&locale=en_US&VIEWER_URL=/view/action/singleViewer.do?&DELIVERY_RULE_ID=10&adjacency=N&application=DIGITOOL-3&frameId=1&usePid1=true&usePid2=true|website=Colorado State University Libraries}}</ref>
Near the [[sun]], [[solar cell]] performance deteriorates from high incident [[Flux|particle flux]] and high temperatures from [[heat flux]].<ref name=berlin9>{{cite journal|last1=Raag|first1=V.|last2=Berlin|first2=R.E.|title=A silicon-germanium solar thermoelectric generator|journal=Energy Conversion|date=December 1968|volume=8|issue=4|pages=161–168|doi=10.1016/0013-7480(68)90033-8}}</ref> However, thermoelectric energy conversion systems that use [[thermoelectric materials]] (e.g. SiGe alloys) as a supplemental source of power for missions near the sun can operate unprotected in [[vacuum]] and air environments under high temperatures due to their low sensitivity to [[radiation damage]].<ref name=berlin9 /> Such properties have made SiGe thermoelectrics convenient for power generation in [[space]]. The multifoil cold stack assembly, composed of [[molybdenum]], [[tungsten]], [[stainless steel]], [[copper]], and alumina materials, provides the insulation between the [[Electric current|electrical]] and [[Heat current|thermal currents]] of the system. The SiGe n-leg doped with [[boron]] and SiGe p-leg doped with [[phosphorus]] act as the intermediary between the heat source and electrical assembly.
== Power generation == SiGe thermocouples in an RTG convert [[heat]] directly into [[electricity]]. Thermoelectric power generation requires a constantly maintained temperature difference among the junctions of the two dissimilar metals (i.e. Si and Ge) to produce a low power [[Electric circuit|closed circuit]] electric current without extra [[circuitry]] or external power sources.<ref name=dingwall3 /><ref name=antonio11 >{{Cite book|author1=Antonio Sanchez-Torres| title=Radioisotope Power Systems for Space Applications|editor1-last=Singh|editor1-first=Nirmal|journal=Radioisotopes - Applications in Physical Sciences|isbn=978-953-307-510-5|url=http://www.intechopen.com/books/radioisotopes-applications-in-physical-sciences/radioisotope-power-systems-for-space-applications|date=2011}}</ref><ref name=furlong12>{{cite news|last1=Furlong|first1=Richard R.|last2=Wahlquist|first2=Earl J.|title=U.S. Space Missions Using Radioisotope Power Systems.|url=http://www3.ans.org/pubs/magazines/nn/pdfs/1999-4-2.pdf|agency=American Nuclear Society|publisher=Nuclear News|date=April 1999}}</ref>
A large array of SiGe thermocouples/unicouples form a [[thermopile]] that was incorporated into the design of [[radioisotope thermoelectric generators]] (RTGs) used in the missions ''[[Voyager program|Voyager]]'', ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'', ''[[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]]'', ''[[Cassini (spacecraft)|Cassini]]'', and ''[[New Horizons]]''.<ref name=fleurial10 >{{cite web|last1=Fleurial|first1=Jean-Pierre|last2=Caillat|first2=Thierry|last3=Nesmith|first3=Bill J.|last4=Ewell|first4=Richard C.|last5=Woerner|first5=David F.|last6=Carr|first6=Gregory C.|last7=Jones|first7=Loren E.|id=Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology (2011)| title=Thermoelectrics: From Space Power Systems to Terrestrial Waste Heat Recovery Applications|url=http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2014/03/f13/fluerial.pdf|website=U.S. Department of Energy}}</ref> On these spacecraft, [[Pu-238]] dioxide fuel undergoes [[Radioactive decay|natural decay]]. The SiGe thermocouples/unicouples convert this heat to hundreds of [[Watt]]s of electrical power.<ref name=furlong12 />
== Thermocouple/unicouple assembly == [[File:SiGe Thermocouple Function.png|thumb|Conceptual diagram of a thermocouple (unicouple)]] The [[thermocouples|thermocouples/unicouples]] attached to the outer shell consist of a SiGe alloy [[Doping (semiconductor)|n-leg doped]] with boron and a SiGe [[Doping (semiconductor)|p-leg doped]] with phosphorus to provide thermoelectric polarity to the couple.<ref name=xie6 /><ref name=IECEC >Bennett, G.L; Lombardo, James; Hemler, Richard; Silverman, Gil; Whitmore C.; Amos, Wayne; Johnson, E.; Schock, Alfred; Zocher, Roy; Keenan, Thomas; Hagan, James; and Richard Englehart. [http://www.fas.org/nuke/space/gphs.pdf Mission of Daring: The General-Purpose Heat Source Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator], AIAA 2006-4096, 4th International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference and Exhibit (IECEC), 26–29 June 2006, San Diego, California (Accessed 10 February 2015)</ref> The electrical and thermal currents of the system are separated by bonding the SiGe alloy thermocouple to a multifoil cold stack assembly of [[molybdenum]], [[tungsten]], [[stainless steel]], [[copper]], and alumina components.<ref name=IECEC /> Several layers of [https://web.archive.org/web/20150219015544/http://jpsglass.com/aerospace.html Astroquartz] silica fiber yarn electrically [[insulator (electrical)|insulate]] the legs of the SiGe thermocouples. In between the inner insulation system and the outer shell, copper connectors form the electrical [[Circuit (electronic)|circuit]], which uses a two-string, [[Series and parallel circuits|series-parallel wiring]] design to connect the unicouples.<ref name=antonio11 /> The circuit loop arrangement minimizes the net [[magnetic field]] of the [[Thermoelectric generator|generator]].<ref name=IECEC />
== Application history == [[File:RTG Space Exploration Timeline.png|upright|thumb|RTG Space Exploration Timeline]] SiGe has been used as a material in RTGs since 1976. Each mission that has used RTG technology involves exploration of far-reaching regions of the solar system. The most recent mission, ''New Horizons'' (2005), was originally set for a 3-year exploration, but was extended to 17 years.
=== Multi-hundred-watt (MHW) applications === ''[[Voyager 1]]'' and ''[[Voyager 2]]'' [[spacecraft]] launched in August and September 1977 required [[MHW-RTG|multi-hundred-watt]] ([[MHW-RTG|MHW]]) RTG containing [[plutonium oxide]] fuel spheres for an operational life appropriate for exploration of [[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], [[Uranus]], and [[Neptune]].<ref name=furlong12 /> Conversion of the [[Radioactive decay|decay]] heat of the plutonium to electrical power was accomplished through 312 silicon-germanium (SiGe) thermoelectric couples. A hot junction temperature of 1273 [[Kelvin (unit)|K]] (1832 [[Fahrenheit (degree)|°F]]) with a cold junction temperature of 573 K (572 °F) compose the temperature gradient in the thermoelectric couple in the RTG.<ref name=furlong12 /> This mechanism provided the total electrical power to operate the spacecraft’s instruments, communications and other power demands. The RTG on ''Voyager'' will produce adequate electrical power for spacecraft operation until about the year 2020.<ref name=furlong12 /> Similar MHW-RTG models are also used on the two U.S. Air Force communications [[Lincoln Experimental Satellite|Lincoln Experimental Satellites 8 and 9]] (''[[Lincoln Experimental Satellite|LES-8/9]]'').<ref name=fleurial10 />
=== General Purpose Heat Source (GPHS) applications === The ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'' spacecraft launched on October 18, 1989, the ''[[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]]'' on October 6, 1990, the [[Cassini (spacecraft)|''Cassini'']] on October 15, 1997 and the ''[[New Horizons]]'' on January 19, 2006. All of these spacecraft contain the [[GPHS-RTG|general purpose heat source (GPHS)]] RTG commissioned by the [[U.S. Department of Energy]].<ref name=antonio11 /> The GPHS-RTG employs identical heat-to-electrical conversion technology used in the [[MHW-RTG]]s from the ''Voyager'' missions, using SiGe thermocouples/unicouples and the Pu-238–fueled GPHS.<ref name=furlong12 /> ''New Horizons'' made its historic flyby past [[Pluto]] and its moons on July 14, 2015 ([http://pluto.jhuapl.edu/ see JHU Applied Physics website]). The spacecraft's next destination will be a small [[Kuiper Belt]] object (KBO) known as [[2014 MU69]] that orbits nearly a billion miles beyond [[Pluto]]. <ref>https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-s-new-horizons-team-selects-potential-kuiper-belt-flyby-target</ref> Based on performance, data and modeling for the SiGe alloy RTGs, the GPHS-RTGs on ''Ulysses'', ''Cassini'' and ''New Horizons'' are expected to meet or exceed the remaining power performance requirements for their deep-space missions.<ref name=dingwall3 />
== RTG alternative == Missions after 2010 requiring RTGs will instead use the [[Multi-Mission Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator]] (MMRTG) containing [[lead telluride]] (PbTe) thermocouples and Pu-238 dioxide for spacecraft power applications.{{Citation needed|date=June 2016}}
== See also == * [[Radioisotope thermoelectric generator|Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator (RTG)]] * [[Silicon-germanium|Silicon-germanium (SiGe)]] * [[Thermocouple]] * [[Thermoelectric effect]] * [[Thermoelectric cooling]] * [[GPHS-RTG|General Purpose Heat Source (GPHS)-RTG]] * [[Multi-Mission Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator|Multi-Mission (MMRTG)]] * [[Advanced Stirling Radioisotope Generator]] * [[Radioisotope heater units]]

{{Infobox dam | name = Bakhtiari Dam | name_official = | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | image_alt = | location_map = Iran | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|32|57|23.58|N|48|45|34.87|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = [[Iran]] | location = [[Aligudarz County]], [[Lorestan Province|Lorestan]]<ref name="hamshahrionline 2017">{{cite web | title=آشنایی با سد بختیاری - لرستان | website=hamshahrionline | date=2017-04-28 | url=http://hamshahrionline.ir/details/206467 | language=fa | accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref> | status =UC | construction_began = 25 March 2013 | opening = | demolished = | cost = $2 billion [[USD]] | owner = | dam_type = Arch | dam_height = {{Convert|325|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}<ref name=bakinfo/> | dam_length = {{Convert|434|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} | dam_width_crest = {{Convert|10|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} | dam_width_base = {{Convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} | dam_volume = {{Convert|3100000|m3|ft3|0|abbr=on}} | dam_crosses = [[Bakhtiari River]] | spillway_count = | spillway_type = Service, gate-controlled | spillway_capacity = {{Convert|5830|m3/s|ft3/s|0|abbr=on}} | res_name = Bakhtiari Reservoir | res_capacity_total = {{Convert|4845000000|m3|acre.ft|0|abbr=on}} | res_catchment = {{Convert|6288|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} | res_surface = {{Convert|58.7|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} | res_max_depth = | plant_hydraulic_head = {{Convert|289|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} (max.) | res_tidal_range = | plant_operator = | plant_commission = | plant_decommission = | plant_type = | plant_turbines = 6 × 250 [[megawatt|MW]] [[Francis turbine|Francis type]] | plant_capacity = 1,500 MW | plant_annual_gen = 3 billion [[kWh]] (est.) | website = [http://en.iwpco.ir/Bakhtiari/default.aspx en.iwpco.ir/Bakhtiari/] | extra = }} The '''Bakhtiari Dam''' is an [[arch dam]] currently under construction on the [[Bakhtiari River]] within the [[Zagros Mountains]] on the border of [[Lorestan Province|Lorestan]] and [[Khuzestan Province]]s, [[Iran]]. At a planned height of {{convert|325|m}},<ref name=bakinfo/> it will be the world's tallest dam once completed and withhold the second largest reservoir in Iran after the [[Karkheh Dam|Karkheh]] reservoir. The main purpose of the dam is [[hydroelectric]] power production and it will support a 1,500 MW power station. By trapping sediment, the dam is also expected to extend the life of the [[Dez Dam]] {{Convert|50|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} downstream.
==Background== Preliminary studies for the dam began in 1996 and were carried out by Mahab Qods Consulting Engineers. The studies were carried out over a period of 33 months and in March 2000, the results were given to Iran Water & Power Resources Development Co (IWPCO). In May 2005, IWPCO awarded consultation services for the project to Moshanir Consulting Engineers, Dezab Consulting Engineers, Econo-Electrowatt/Boyri and Stucky Pars Consulting Engineers.<ref name=bakinfo>{{cite web|title=Bakhtiari Project Information|url=http://en.iwpco.ir/Bakhtiari/default.aspx|publisher=IWPCO|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On April 30, 2007 the construction contract was awarded to China's [[Sinohydro Corporation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New Awarded Projects |url=http://www.farab.com/en/projects/HPrj/project_list.asp?tPk=1 |publisher=FARAB Co. |accessdate=30 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710224430/http://www.farab.com/en/projects/HPrj/project_list.asp?tPk=1 |archivedate=10 July 2011 }}</ref> The contract is worth $2 billion and was to be funded with direct investment from China.<ref>{{cite web|title=Iran News Roundup October 6, 2010|url=http://www.irantracker.org/roundup/iran-news-roundup-october-6-2010|publisher=Iran Tracker|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=China dams overseas|url=http://eprf.probeinternational.org/node/8501|publisher=Probe International|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Sinohydro signed the 118-month contract on March 15, 2011 and was expected to be working with Iran's Farab.<ref>{{cite news|title=SINOHYDRO Signed the Contract to Build Iran’s Bakhtiary Project|url=http://eng.sinohydro.com/en/idems/newsShow.asp?ArticleID=228&ClassID=2|accessdate=8 May 2011|newspaper=Sinohydro Corporation|date=15 Mar 2011}}</ref> But the Iranian government rejected Sinohydro's bid in late May 2012 and handed the project over to [[Khatam-al-Anbiya]] (KAA), which is controlled by the [[Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Iranian contractor to build world’s tallest arch dam, Chinese bid rejected |url=http://tehrantimes.com/economy-and-business/98368-iranian-contractor-to-build-worlds-tallest-arch-dam-chinese-bid-rejected |publisher=Tehran Times |accessdate=30 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531234647/http://www.tehrantimes.com/economy-and-business/98368-iranian-contractor-to-build-worlds-tallest-arch-dam-chinese-bid-rejected |archivedate=31 May 2012 }}</ref> The KAA commander announced on 19 December 2012 that construction of the dam had begun with access roads leading to the project site.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran starts building second-tallest dam |url=http://gantdaily.com/2012/12/20/iran-starts-building-second-tallest-dam/ |accessdate=3 March 2013 |newspaper=Gant Daily |date=20 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228131244/http://gantdaily.com/2012/12/20/iran-starts-building-second-tallest-dam/ |archivedate=28 December 2012 |df= }}</ref> On 25 March 2013, Iranian President [[Mahmood Ahmadinejad]] attended a groundbreaking ceremony for the dam, initiating its construction.<ref>{{cite web|title=News: Bakhtiari, World 's Highest Dam, Kicks off in the Presence of Mahmood Ahmadinejad |url=http://en.iwpco.ir/Lists/News/DispForm.aspx?ID=159 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424093027/http://en.iwpco.ir/Lists/News/DispForm.aspx?ID=159 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 April 2014 |publisher=Iran Water and Power Resources Development Co. |accessdate=6 May 2013 |date=13 April 2013 }}</ref>
==Construction== During construction, a total of six bridges will be built to support workers, vehicles and equipment in addition to various access roads. To divert the river, two tunnels, {{Convert|1151|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|1180|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} in length will be constructed at the dam's left abutment. They will have discharge capacities of {{Convert|2090|m3/s|cuft/s|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|1680|m3/s|cuft/s|0|abbr=on}} respectively. To divert the water, two [[roller-compacted concrete]] [[cofferdam]]s will be constructed. The upstream cofferdam will be {{Convert|51|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} high and the downstream {{Convert|25|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. Material to construct the dam including [[construction aggregate|aggregate]] will come from the actual excavation of the dam site along with three quarries in the area.<ref name=bakspec/>
==Design== The Bakhtiari will be a {{Convert|325|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall and {{Convert|434|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} long variable-radius arch dam. It will be {{Convert|10|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} wide at its crest and {{Convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} wide at its base while being composed of {{Convert|3100000|m3|ft3|0|abbr=on}} of concrete. The dam's [[reservoir]] will have a normal capacity of {{Convert|4845000000|m3|acre.ft|0|abbr=on}} and an active or "useful" capacity of {{Convert|3070000000|m3|acre.ft|0|abbr=on}}. At a normal elevation of {{Convert|830|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} above sea level, the reservoir will have a surface area of {{Convert|58.7|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}, maximum width of {{Convert|1|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} and length of {{Convert|59|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}. Its [[drainage basin|catchment area]] will be {{Convert|6288|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name=bakspec>{{cite web|title=Bakhtiari Technical Specifications |url=http://en.iwpco.ir/Bakhtiari/TechInfo.aspx |publisher=IWPCO |accessdate=30 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815163612/http://en.iwpco.ir/Bakhtiari/TechInfo.aspx |archivedate=15 August 2011 }}</ref>
The dam will contain two [[spillway]]s. The main service spillway will be an {{Convert|11|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} diameter tunnel in the right abutment with two flood gates. The discharge capacity of this spillway will be {{Convert|5830|m3/s|ft3/s|0|abbr=on}}. The second spillway will be two radial gates on the dam's orifice with a discharge capacity of {{Convert|1510|m3/s|ft3/s|0|abbr=on}}. The dam's powerhouse will be [[underground power station|located underground]] at the left abutment. It will be {{Convert|161|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} long, {{Convert|64|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} high and {{Convert|24|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} wide; containing 6 x 250 [[megawatt|MW]] vertical [[Francis turbine]]-generators. Before reaching the power station, water will be transferred by six {{Convert|51|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} long [[penstock]]s. Feeding water to the penstocks is a {{Convert|504|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} long headrace tunnel with a three gate intake structure.<ref name=bakspec/>

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date = October 2012}} {{cleanup|date = October 2012|reason = the article needs wikilinking, formatting and perhaps an expert from a relevant project}} }} [[File:Electrical bushing assortment 1954.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Assortment of small ceramic bushings for voltages from a few hundred to a few thousand volts.]]
In [[electric power]], a '''bushing''' is an [[insulator (electricity)|insulated]] device that allows an electrical conductor to pass safely through a grounded conducting barrier such as the case of a transformer or circuit breaker. Bushings are typically made from [[porcelain]], though other materials are possible.
==Explanation== All materials carrying an [[electric charge]] generate an [[electric field]]. When an energized conductor is near a material at earth potential, it can form very high field strengths, especially where the [[field line]]s are forced to curve sharply around the earthed material. The bushing controls the shape and strength of the field and reduces the electrical stresses in the insulating material.
==Bushing condenser== A bushing must be designed to withstand the electrical field strength produced in the insulation, when any earthed material is present. As the strength of the electrical field increases, leakage paths may develop within the insulation. If the energy of the leakage path overcomes the dielectric strength of the insulation, it may puncture the insulation and allow the electrical energy to conduct to the nearest earthed material causing burning and arcing.
A typical bushing design has a 'conductor', (usually of copper or aluminium, occasionally of other conductive materials), surrounded by insulation, except for the terminal ends.
In the case of a busbar, the conductor terminals will support the busbar in its location. In the case of a bushing, a fixing device will also be attached to the insulation to hold it in its location. Usually, the fixing point is integral or surrounds the insulation over part of the insulated surface. The insulated material between the fixing point and the conductor is the most highly stressed area.
The design of any electrical bushing must ensure that the electrical strength of the insulated material is able to withstand the penetrating 'electrical energy' passing through the conductor, via any highly stressed areas. It must also be capable of enduring, occasional and exceptional high voltage moments as well as the normal continual service withstand voltage, as it is the voltage that directs and controls the development of leakage paths and not current.
Insulated bushings can be installed either indoor, or outdoor, and the selection of insulation will be determined by the location of the installation and the electrical service duty on the bushing.
For a bushing to work successfully over many years, the insulation must remain effective both in composition and design shape and will be key factors in its survival. Bushings can therefore vary considerably in both material and design style.
==Types==
===Porcelain insulation=== The earliest bushing designs use electro porcelain for both indoor and outdoor applications. [[Porcelain]] is impervious to moisture once sealed by fired glaze and is low cost and flexible to manufacture. The main disadvantage with porcelain is that its small value of linear expansion has to be accommodated by using flexible seals and substantial metal fittings, both of which present manufacturing and operational problems.
A basic porcelain bushing is a hollow porcelain shape that fits through a hole in a wall or metal case, allowing a conductor to pass through its center, and connect at both ends to other equipment. Bushings of this type are often made of wet-process fired porcelain, which is then glazed. A semi-conducting glaze may be used to assist in equalizing the electrical potential gradient along the length of the bushing.
The inside of the porcelain bushing is often filled with oil to provide additional insulation and bushings of this construction are widely used up to 36 KV where higher partial discharges are permitted.
Where [[partial discharge]] is required to conform to IEC60137, paper and resin insulated conductors are used in conjunction with porcelain, for unheated indoor and outdoor applications.
The use of resin (polymer, polymeric, composite) insulated bushings for high voltage applications is common, although most high-voltage bushings are usually made of resin impregnated paper insulation around the conductor with porcelain or polymer weather sheds, for the outdoor end and occasionally for the indoor end.
===Paper insulation=== Another early form of insulation was paper, however, paper is hygroscopic and absorbs moisture which is detrimental and is disadvantaged by the inflexible linear designs. Cast resin technology, has dominated insulated products since the 1960s, due to its flexibility of shape and its higher dielectrical strength.
Typically, paper insulation is later impregnated either with oil (historically), or more commonly today with resin. In the case of resin, the paper is film coated with a Phenolic resin to become Synthetic Resin Bonded Paper, (SRBP) or impregnated after dry winding with epoxy resins, to become Resin Impregnated Paper or Epoxy Resin Impregnated Paper (RIP, ERIP).
SRBP insulated bushings are typically used up to voltages around 72.5 kV. However, above 12 kV, there is a need to control the external electrical field and to even out the internal energy storage which marginalises the dielectric strength of paper insulation.
To improve the performance of paper insulated bushings, metallic foils can be inserted during the winding process. These act to stabilize the generated electrical fields, homogenising the internal energy using the effect of capacitance. This feature resulted in the Condenser/Capacitor bushing.
The condenser bushing is made by inserting very fine layers of metallic foil into the paper during the winding process. The inserted conductive foils produce a capacitive effect which dissipates the electrical energy more evenly throughout the insulated paper and reduces the electric field stress between the energised conductor and any earthed material.
Condenser bushings produce electric stress fields which are significantly less potent around the fixing flange than designs without foils and, when used in conjunction with resin impregnation, produce bushings which can be used at service voltages over one million with great success.
===Resin insulation=== Since the 1965s, resin materials have been used for all types of bushing up to the highest voltages. The flexibility of using a castable form of insulation has replaced paper insulation in many product areas and dominates the existing insulated bushing market.
As with paper insulation, the control of electric stress fields remains important. Resin insulation has greater dielectric strength than paper and requires less stress control at voltages below 25 kV. However, some compact and higher rated switchgear designs, have earthed materials closer to bushings than in the past and these designs may require stress control screens in resin bushings operating as low as 12 kV Fixing points are often integral with the main resin form, and present fewer problems to earthed materials than the metal flanges used on paper bushings. However, care must be observed in resin insulated bushings designs which use internally cast screens such that the benefit of electrical stress field control is not off set by increasing partial discharge caused by the difficulties of eliminating micro voids in the resin around the screens during the casting process. The need to eliminate voids in resin becomes more sensitive as voltages increases, and it is normal to revert to resin impregnated, foiled paper insulation for bushings rated over 72.5 kV.
<gallery mode=packed> Электрорезонансный трансформатор напряжения.jpg|Bushings on small [[Voltage regulator#Constant-voltage transformer|ferroresonant transformer]] Polemount-singlephase-closeup.jpg|Bushings on single phase distribution transformer Schwabenheim Kraftwerk Trafos.jpg|20 kV bushings on transformers and cables Kabelendverschluss_Fellbach.jpg|110 kV bushings in a building wall Elfmorgenbruch_220kV-Transformator.jpg|Bushings for 110 kV and 220 kV Kändelweg Umspanner.jpg|Bushings on 380 kV transformer and [[Switchgear#Gas|GIS]] connection Bundesarchiv Bild 102-11603, Prüf-Transformator der AEG.jpg|Bushing on 1 MV AEG utility transformer, Germany, 1932 </gallery>
== Bushing failure == {{multiple image | direction = horizontal | header = | image1 =Dr_bushing_7.png | caption1 = Dry bushing | width1 = 60 | image2 =Dr_bushing_10.png | caption2 = Oil filled capacitor bushing | width2 = 60 | image3 =Dr_bushing_13.png | caption3 = Oil filled capacitor bushing | width3 = 60 | footer = }} Bushings sometimes fail due to [[partial discharge]]. This is sometimes due to the slow and progressive degradation of the insulation over many years of energized service; however it may also be a rapid degeneration which destroys a good bushing in a matter of hours. At present, there is great interest by the electricity supply industry in monitoring the condition of high voltage bushings. However, some bushings failing early in service are due to failures to control voltage or carry out essential maintenance, while others relate to incipient failure mechanisms built in at manufacture. This view is evidenced by the minority of bushing failures worldwide.
==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite book | author=Central Electricity Generating Board | title=Modern Power Station Practice |publisher=Pergamon | year=1982 | isbn=0-08-016436-6}} *IEC60137-2008, BEAIRA Technical Report Q/T123-1952 Design of High Voltage Stress Controlled Condenser-Type Bushings and Capcitors, BEAIRA Technical Report Q/T125-1952 Stresses in High Voltage Condenser Bushings, BSEN 50180, 50181, 50386

[[Barium fluoride]] }} }} '''Calcium fluoride''' is the [[inorganic compound]] of the elements [[calcium]] and [[fluorine]] with the [[chemical formula|formula]] CaF2. It is a white insoluble solid. It occurs as the mineral [[fluorite]] (also called fluorspar), which is often deeply coloured owing to impurities. ==Chemical structure== The compound crystallizes in a cubic motif called a fluorite structure. [[File:Xtals combined 2 300ppi.png|thumb|left|upright=1.5|Unit cell of CaF2, known as fluorite structure, from two equivalent perspectives. The second origin is often used when visualising point defects entered on the cation.{{Cite journal|last=Burr|first=P. A.|last2=Cooper|first2=M. W. D.|date=2017-09-15|title=Importance of elastic finite-size effects: Neutral defects in ionic compounds|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.96.094107|journal=Physical Review B|volume=96|issue=9|pages=094107|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.96.094107}}]] Ca2+ centres are eight-coordinate, being centered in a "box" for eight F− centres. Each F− centre is coordinated to four Ca2+ centres.G. L. Miessler and D. A. Tarr “Inorganic Chemistry” 3rd Ed, Pearson/Prentice Hall publisher, {{ISBN|0-13-035471-6}}. Although perfectly packed crystalline samples are colorless, the mineral is often deeply colored due to the presence of [[F-center]]s. The same crystal structure is found in numerous ionic compounds with formula AB2, such as [[ceria|CeO2]], [[zirconia|cubic ZrO2]], [[uranium dioxide|UO2]], [[thorium dioxide|ThO2]], and [[plutonium dioxide|PuO2]]. A related structure is the antifluorite structure, where the anions and cations are swapped, such as [[beryllium carbide|Be2C]]. ==Preparation== The mineral [[fluorite]] is abundant, widespread, and mainly of interest as a precursor to [[hydrofluoric acid|HF]]. Thus, little motivation exists for the industrial production of CaF2. High purity CaF2 is produced by treating [[calcium carbonate]] with [[hydrofluoric acid]]:{{cite journal|last1=Aigueperse|first1=Jean|last2=Mollard|first2=Paul|last3=Devilliers|first3=Didier|last4=Chemla|first4=Marius|last5=Faron|first5=Robert|last6=Romano|first6=René|last7=Cuer|first7=Jean Pierre|title=Fluorine Compounds, Inorganic|year=2000|doi=10.1002/14356007.a11_307}} :CaCO3 + 2 HF → CaF2 + CO2 + H2O ==Applications== {{Main|Fluorite}} Naturally occurring CaF2 is the principal source of [[hydrogen fluoride]], a commodity chemical used to produce a wide range of materials. Calcium fluoride in the [[fluorite]] state is of significant commercial importance as a fluoride source.Aigueperse, Jean; Mollard, Paul; Devilliers, Didier; Chemla, Marius; Faron, Robert; Romano, Renée; Cuer, Jean Pierre (2005), "Fluorine Compounds, Inorganic", Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Weinheim: Wiley-VCH, p. 307, doi:10.1002/14356007.a11_307. Hydrogen fluoride is liberated from the mineral by the action of concentrated [[sulfuric acid]]:Holleman, A. F.; Wiberg, E. "Inorganic Chemistry" Academic Press: San Diego, 2001. {{ISBN|0-12-352651-5}}. :CaF2 + H2SO4 → [[calcium sulfate|CaSO4]](solid) + 2 HF ===Niche uses=== Calcium fluoride is used to manufacture optical components such as windows and lenses, used in thermal imaging systems, spectroscopy, [[telescope|telescopes]], and [[excimer laser]]s. It is transparent over a broad range from ultraviolet (UV) to infrared (IR) frequencies. Its low refractive index reduces the need for [[anti-reflection coating]]s. Its insolubility in water is convenient as well. Doped calcium fluoride, like natural fluorite, exhibits [[thermoluminescence]] and is used in [[thermoluminescent dosimeter]]s. ==Safety== CaF2 is classified as "not dangerous", although reacting it with [[sulfuric acid]] produces toxic [[hydrofluoric acid]]. With regards to inhalation, the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|NIOSH]]-recommended concentration of fluorine-containing dusts is 2.5 mg/m3 in air. ==See also== *[[List of laser types]] *[[Photolithography]] *[[Skeletal fluorosis]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://webbook.nist.gov/cgi/cbook.cgi?ID=7789-75-5&Units=SI NIST webbook] thermochemistry data *[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/284158_townes.html Charles Townes on the history of lasers] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060116134617/http://www.npi.gov.au/database/substance-info/profiles/44.html National Pollutant Inventory - Fluoride and compounds fact sheet] *[http://www.crystran.co.uk/calcium-fluoride-caf2.htm Crystran Material Data] *[http://msds.chem.ox.ac.uk/CA/calcium_fluoride.html MSDS] (University of Oxford) {{Calcium compounds}} {{Fluorine compounds}} [[Category:Calcium compounds]] [[Category:Crystals]] [[Category:Fluorides]] [[Category:Fluorite]] [[Category:Metal halides]] [[Category:Optical materials]]

{{distinguish|Troodon}} {{refimprove|date=February 2012}} [[File:Blason Cire Trudon.jpg|thumb|Armorial of Cire Trudon]] '''Cire Trudon''' is a French candlemaker and the oldest [[wax]]-producing factory worldwide. Founded in 1643, it was the provider of the royal court of [[Louis XIV]], as well as most of the great churches of [[France]].
Cire Trudon was the biggest wax-producing factory in the French Kingdom during the 17th and 18th centuries. In 1762, in his encyclopaedia ''The art of the wax producer'', engineer [[Henri-Louis Duhamel du Monceau|Duhamel du Monceau]], praises the skills of the Trudons and gives the manufacture as an example. Such a level of quality led to King [[Louis XIV]] elevating Charles Trudon to the [[French nobility]] as Count Trudon des Ormes.
==History==
===Claude Trudon=== In 1643, a salesman named Claude Trudon arrived in Paris. He soon became the owner of a shop on [[Rue Saint-Honoré|Saint-Honoré]], which provided its customers with wax, [[candle]]s for any domestic usage as well as church candles to the neighbouring [[Saint Roch]] parish. The candles were homemade, developing and building on a specific manufacturing process. On the eve of the reign of [[Louis XIV]], M. Trudon established his first family-owned factory which was to bear his name and make the fortune of his heirs.
===Jacques Trudon=== Claude's son Jacques took over, becoming a grocer and wax producer and joined the [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] royal court in 1687 as the apothecary and distiller of Queen Marie-Thérèse.
At the time, wax was under high scrutiny. Carefully collected on the hive, it was bleached through a series of pure water baths that washed off all the impurities. Dried in the open air, the wax was whitened by sunlight. When burning, the flame lit the translucent edges generating the glowing aura of the candle.
===Jérôme Trudon=== In 1737, Jérôme Trudon, heir of the family, purchased one of the most famous wax producing factories of the times that belonged to Lord Pean de Saint Gilles. Pean de Saint Gilles was then the official wax provider to the King. Drawing from the family expertise, Hierosme devoted his skills to the development of a vast factory. Skilful and very demanding, he produced a wax of very high quality, collecting it from the best hives of the kingdom and trading directly with the producers. The wax was then treated with the utmost attention: it was washed with the purest water after being filtered with gypsum, guaranteeing the highest quality. The factory also imported the finest cotton to manufacture wicks whose combustion was clean and regular. The Trudon candles, so white and so perfect, could burn for hours without crackling; their flame neither trembled nor smoked.
Maison Trudon furnished candles to the royal court, and cathedrals and churches over France. More than one hundred people worked at the time in a very large building – now registered in the French inventory of historical monuments – in the city of [[Antony, Hauts-de-Seine]]. Its Latin motto and its blazon are engraved on a stone board of the factory building: a depiction of hives and bees bordered by the saying: ''Deo regique laborant'' ("they work for God and for the King" — they meaning the bees).
==Cire Trudon today== Cire Trudon still keep records of recipe and tools of wax whitening: wrought iron, 17th century pans. The moulds used to form candles bearing the royal blazons still remain: "''cierge pascal pour la Chapelle du Roy à [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]], Bougies de nuit pour le Roy...''" ("Easter candle church for the Royal Chapel in Versailles, night candle for the King...")
Cire Trudon supplied the [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] castle until the end of the monarchy. During his captivity, [[Louis XVI]] used the candles of his royal wax manufacturer. The blazon and the motto would be hidden under a layer of mortar to avoid the furies of the Revolution.
It is still today the candle provider of many churches, like [[Saint-Roch, Paris|Saint-Roch]] church in Paris, which has burned their candles since 1643. The brand was successfully relaunched in 2006 .
The manufacturer distributes its products in France and abroad.
== Sources ==
* Trudon in the Encyclopedia [https://books.google.com/books?id=KnM5AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA20&dq=trudon+cirier&as_brr=0#PPA20,M1 "Bibliothèque des sciences, et des beaux arts" (1754)] * Trudon in the book [https://books.google.com/books?as_brr=0&id=aTg1AAAAIAAJ&dq=trudon+cirier&q=trudon&pgis=1 "Napoléon et son fils" (1929)]
== External links == * [http://www.ciretrudon.com/ Cire Trudon] * Trudon cited in: ** [[Honoré de Balzac]]'s [http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/docs/books/gutenberg/etext01/2rthc10.txt The Human Comedy] ** [http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/docs/books/gutenberg/etext01/2rthc10.txt The Rise and Fall of Cesar Birotteau]
